title: How to Fix a Cassette Tape

steps.title: Unscrew the cassette case, if it has screws, using a small Phillips screwdriver.
steps.content: Unscrew the cassette case, if it has screws, using a small Phillips screwdriver. Use a tiny Phillips-head screwdriver to remove the screws in the two top corners of the cassette tape. Set the screws aside somewhere where you won’t lose them, such as in a small dish or cup. [1] X Research source If you don’t see any screws, your cassette is the type that is glued together. Issues that you will need to take a cassette tape apart to fix include a ripped or broken tape and a tape that has come off one of the wheel hubs.

steps.title: Pry the cassette apart using a tiny flathead screwdriver, if it is glued together.
steps.content: Pry the cassette apart using a tiny flathead screwdriver, if it is glued together. Insert the edge of the flathead screwdriver into the crack where the front and back pieces of the case are glued together on one side of the cassette. Work it back and forth in a lever motion along the crack to gently break the two halves apart. [2] X Research source If you can’t pry the cassette case apart with your hands after separating the halves on one side, repeat the process with the screwdriver for the other sides of the cassette until you can pull them apart.

steps.title: Open the cassette tape horizontally so the spools don’t fall out.
steps.content: Open the cassette tape horizontally so the spools don’t fall out. Place the tape horizontally on a flat surface before you open it up. Pull the top half off and try to leave the bottom half flat on your work surface. [3] X Research source This will keep the wheel hubs in place so you don’t accidentally drop them out and cause more damage to the tape.

steps.title: Use small, sharp scissors to cut off the damaged ends of the broken tape.
steps.content: Use small, sharp scissors to cut off the damaged ends of the broken tape. Put the two halves of the cassette tape flat on the cutting board with the insides facing up at you. Be careful not to uncoil the tape from the wheel hubs. [4] X Research source Carefully trim off as little of the tape as possible, so you are only removing the damaged parts of the tape where it ripped and broke. This will allow you to tape the two pieces neatly back together. [5] X Research source If you don’t have a pair of small, sharp scissors, you can carefully cut the damaged ends off using a boxcutter or utility knife and your cutting board. Depending how much damaged tape you have to cut off, there could be a noticeable skip in the audio of the tape after you splice it back together.

steps.title: Tape one end of the broken tape down on the cutting board.
steps.content: Tape one end of the broken tape down on the cutting board. Straighten out one of the sides of the broken tape flat against the cutting board and carefully tape it down. Leave the end you trimmed exposed. [6] X Research source Make sure that the broken end of the tape is completely flat and not curling at all, so that it is easy to work with when you’re splicing the other broken end to it.

steps.title: Use cellophane tape to splice the two sides of the cassette’s tape together.
steps.content: Use cellophane tape to splice the two sides of the cassette’s tape together. Carefully line up the end of the other side of the broken tape with the end of the side you just taped down. Press a piece of cellophane tape down over them to splice them together. [7] X Research source The spliced pieces will be held down on the cutting board by the cellophane tape at this point.

steps.title: Peel up the cellophane tape and flip the cassette’s tape over on the cutting board.
steps.content: Peel up the cellophane tape and flip the cassette’s tape over on the cutting board. Use your fingernails to gently peel the cellophane tape up from the cutting board, being careful not to unsplice the two halves of the cassette’s tape that you just stuck together. Flip over the tape so you can splice together the other side. [8] X Research source The sticky side of the cellophane tape and the side of the cassette’s tape that has no cellophane tape on it should now be facing upwards towards you.

steps.title: Put a piece of cellophane tape on the other side of spliced tape.
steps.content: Put a piece of cellophane tape on the other side of spliced tape. Double-check to make sure the ends of the broken tape are still lined up and stuck together. Carefully stick a new piece of cellophane tape over the exposed sides of the cassette’s tape to finish splicing the broken ends together. [9] X Research source This should hold the broken tape securely together and limit the chances of it coming undone in the future.

steps.title: Trim the excess cellophane tape off using a boxcutter or utility knife.
steps.content: Trim the excess cellophane tape off using a boxcutter or utility knife. Hold the tape flat against the cutting board. Carefully trim the excess cellophane tape that is hanging off the sides of the spliced tape, right up to the edge of the tape. [10] X Research source You can now put the cassette tape back together.

steps.title: Buy a new blank cassette tape to use for parts and open it up.
steps.content: Buy a new blank cassette tape to use for parts and open it up. Purchase a blank cassette that is held together by screws. Unscrew it using a Phillips screwdriver and take it apart, just like you did for the cassette tape you want to fix. [11] X Research source If you have a cassette tape that has come off one of the hubs, it is very difficult to reattach it to the same hub. Using a new wheel tape from a blank cassette that already has tape attached to it will allow you to splice the old tape to it to attach it to a new hub more easily.

steps.title: Cut the new cassette’s tape 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) from the end of the tape.
steps.content: Cut the new cassette’s tape 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) from the end of the tape. The plastic, non-magnetic end of the tape that secures the magnetic tape to the wheel hub is called the leader tape. Remove the spool that has the leader tape exposed from the cassette and cut the tape 1–2 in (2.5–5.1 cm) from the end of the leader tape using small, sharp scissors. [12] X Research source This will give you a new spool with a clean-cut piece of tape to splice the tape from your old cassette to, so that it is attached to the new wheel hub.

steps.title: Remove the wheel hubs from your old cassette.
steps.content: Remove the wheel hubs from your old cassette. Lift out the empty wheel hub and throw it away. Take out the wheel hub that has the tape spooled around it and set it down in front of you. [13] X Research source It’s best to do this on a cutting board on a flat work surface in front of you.

steps.title: Splice the tape from the new wheel hub to the tape on the old hub.
steps.content: Splice the tape from the new wheel hub to the tape on the old hub. Line up the cut end of the new blank tape with the end of the tape from your old cassette. Tape them carefully together using cellophane tape. [14] X Research source See the above method for complete instructions on how to splice cassette tape together.

steps.title: Place the wheel hub back in the cassette case.
steps.content: Place the wheel hub back in the cassette case. Carefully put each wheel hub back into the old cassette so that the holes in the middles of the hubs line up with the holes in the cassette case. Use a pencil to wind the wheel hubs so the tape is not loose and all over the place. [15] X Research source You can now reassemble the cassette tape.

steps.title: Line up the tape with the rollers and pressure pad at the top of the cassette case.
steps.content: Line up the tape with the rollers and pressure pad at the top of the cassette case. Make sure the tape is spooled tightly so it is straight and flat at the top. Place the tape over the rollers that are located in each of the top corners. Put the tape underneath the pressure pad, which is in the center of the top of the cassette. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Screw the cassette case together if it has screws.
steps.content: Screw the cassette case together if it has screws. Snap the two halves of the cassette case back together and place the tiny screws back in the holes in the corners of the case. Use a small Phillips screwdriver to tighten them all the way. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Glue the cassette case together if it doesn’t have screws.
steps.content: Glue the cassette case together if it doesn’t have screws. Put a small dot of superglue in each corner on the edge of one half of the cassette case. Snap the two halves of the case together and hold them together for 30 seconds. [18] X Research source It’s best not to glue all the way around the cassette tape, just in case you have to take it apart again in the future.
